text:
CVE-2023-44487 MITRE: CVE-2023-44487 HTTP/2 Rapid Reset Attack 
In the Workarounds section, corrected the font for the DWORD values "EnableHttp2Tls" (TLS as in Transport Layer Security) and EnableHttp2Cleartext for readability. Note that the "I" should be interpreted as "L" and not an "i". 
MITRE: CVE-2023-44487 HTTP/2 Rapid Reset Attack 
On this page 
 
CVE-2023-44487 
Security Vulnerability 
Released: Oct 10, 2023 Last updated: Oct 16, 2023 
Assigning CNA: 
MITRE Corporation 
CVE-2023-44487  
 
Impact: Denial of Service 
Max Severity: Important 
The following table provides an  
exploitability assessment 
 for this vulnerability at the time of original publication. 
Publicly disclosed 
Exploited 
Exploitability assessment 
No 
Yes 
Exploitation Detected 
The following  
workarounds 
 might be helpful in your situation. In all cases, Microsoft strongly recommends that you install the updates for this vulnerability as soon as possible even if you plan to leave either of these workarounds in place: 
Disable the HTTP/2 protocol on your web server by using the Registry Editor 
Note 
 Using Registry Editor incorrectly can cause serious problems that may require you to reinstall your operating system. Microsoft cannot guarantee that problems resulting from the incorrect use of Registry Editor can be solved. Use Registry Editor at your own risk. For information about how to edit the registry, view the "Changing Keys and Values" Help topic in Registry Editor (Regedit.exe) or view the "Add and Delete Information in the Registry" and "Edit Registry Data" Help topics in Regedt32.exe. 
Click  
Start 
, click  
Run 
, type  
Regedit 
 in the  
Open 
 box, and then click  
OK 
. 
.
 Locate and then click the following registry subkey: 
HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\HTTP\Parameters 
Set  
DWORD 
 type values  
EnableHttp2Tls 
 and  
EnableHttp2Cleartext 
 to one of the following: 
Set to  
0 
 to disable HTTP/2 
Set to  
1 
 to enable HTTP/2 
Exit Registry Editor. 
Restart the computer. 
Include a protocols setting for each Kestrel endpoint to limit your application to HTTP1.1 
For .NET and Kestrel, servers without HTTP/2 enabled are not affected. To limit your application to HTTP1.1 via config, edit your appsettings.json to include a protocols setting for each endpoint: 
"Kestrel": {
   "Endpoints": { 
     "http": { 
       // your existing config 
       "Protocols": "Http1" 
     }, 
     "https": { 
        // your existing config 
       "Protocols": "Http1" 
     } 
   } 
 } 
``` 
Amazon, Cloudflare, and Google

Acknowledgements 
 for more information. 
To determine the support lifecycle for your software, see the  
Microsoft Support Lifecycle

metadata.title: CVE-2023-44487 MITRE: CVE-2023-44487 HTTP/2 Rapid Reset Attack
metadata.description: In the Workarounds section, corrected the font for the DWORD values "EnableHttp2Tls" (TLS as in Transport Layer Security) and EnableHttp2Cleartext for readability. Note that the "I" should be interpreted as "L" and not an "i".
metadata.summary: The CVE-2023-44487 vulnerability affects various Microsoft products, including Windows Server, Windows 10, Windows 11, ASP.NET Core, Microsoft Visual Studio, and .NET. It is a Denial of Service (DoS) vulnerability with a maximum severity of Important. The vulnerability is related to the HTTP/2 protocol and can be exploited to cause a DoS condition. Microsoft has provided workarounds to mitigate the risk, including disabling the HTTP/2 protocol on web servers using Registry Editor and limiting applications to HTTP1.1 via configuration settings for Kestrel endpoints. It's crucial to install the security updates for the affected products as soon as possible. The impact of exploitation could lead to service unavailability, affecting the availability and reliability of web services and applications. System administrators should carefully follow the provided workarounds, considering the potential risks associated with Registry Editor modifications. Microsoft has released security updates for the affected products, addressing the vulnerability and providing protection against potential exploitation.
metadata.nvd_description: the http/2 protocol allows a denial of service (server resource consumption) because request cancellation can reset many streams quickly, as exploited in the wild in august through october 2023.
